info.game_comments:
Ken Jennings game 57.

(Tie Domi: Hi, I'm Tie Domi of the Toronto Maple Leafs.  Watch Jeopardy! or you're gonna have to drop the gloves with me.)
(Alex: Come on.  You want a piece of this, huh?)

(2, 1).clue: (Alex and Tie Domi of the Toronto Maple Leafs are both suited up and on the ice to play some hockey.)  If Tie Domi crosses the blue line before I get the puck to him, we'll be guilty of this infraction

(3, 1).clue: Created by C.W. Post in 1897, this breakfast cereal does not contain either of the two components in its name

(4, 1).clue: Her parents chose Anne Sullivan as her private teacher on the advice of Alexander Graham Bell

(5, 1).clue: This famous nickname of Ty Cobb sounds like a state fruit

(6, 1).clue: This pivoted device supports a bicycle or motorcycle when not in use

(2, 2).clue: To figure out how many points a player has simply add these 2 totals

(3, 2).clue: Macadamias were originally native to this continent

(4, 2).clue: Throughout the 1930s, she taught geography at St. Mary's High School in Eastern India

(5, 2).clue: Abraham Lincoln earned this nickname from his skill in chopping wood in half to make fences

(6, 2).clue: For years, adverstisers have asked us to do this to "your Bic lighter"

(2, 3).clue: (Tie Domi and Alex Trebek pose together on the ice.)  Any player who messes with me will deal with Tie Domi, who has this job--also the name of a "Dirty Harry" film

(3, 3).clue: The Red Delicious apple was originally called the Hawkeye apple; it was developed in an orchard in this state

(4, 3).clue: In 1881 she established the first American Red Cross chapter, in Dansville, New York

(5, 3).clue: Emily Dickinson was "the Belle of" & later "the Nun of" this Massachusetts town

(6, 3).clue: Last name of the golfing great who was the first to twice win the British Open, Masters, PGA & U.S. Open

(2, 4).clue: Bryan Trottier sparked this team to 4 Stanley Cup championships from 1980 through 1983

(3, 4).clue: The name of these sugar, egg white & coconut cookies comes from the same root word as a pasta

(4, 4).clue: The 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution giving women full suffrage was nicknamed for her

(5, 4).clue: General Patton's toughness on his enemies & his own men earned him the nickname "Old" this

(6, 4).clue: It's a billy club carried by a policeman

(2, 5).clue: (Alex shuffles his hockey stick back and forth on the ice.)  It's the 13 letter word for the skill I was just demonstrating (Mario Lemieux doesn't have to worry)

(3, 5).clue: Texas grows a Texas-sized amount of blue corn, often used to make these unleavened flat breads

(4, 5).clue: Among this pacifist's books were "Newer Ideals of Peace" & "Twenty Years at Hull House"

(5, 5).clue: (Hi there.  I’m George Jones.)  You know, early in my career, a deejay gave me this nickname because he thought I resembled a certain American marsupial

(6, 5).clue: These long bloomers were once worn by women & girls as underwear

(1, 1).clue: Sir Walter Scott wrote the book about Scottish outlaw Robert MacGregor, better known as this

(2, 1).clue: As of 2004 this "By The Time I Get To Phoenix" singer was living in Phoenix with his wife & kids

(3, 1).clue: It's the absolute value of negative 143

(5, 1).clue: This disciple said he wouldn't believe in the ressurection until he saw & felt the nail holes in Jesus' hands

(6, 1).clue: Examples include the two-tailed pasha & the zebra swallowtail

(1, 2).clue: 13 years after Sartre wrote "L'etre et le neant", it was translated into "Being and" this

(2, 2).clue: The party was over for him after "Monday Night Football", but he did play himself on "King of the Hill"

(3, 2).clue: A sexagesimal system is based on this number

(5, 2).clue: A "Judas Hole" is the term for the tiny viewing port in one of these; you can watch the man who betrayed you through it

(6, 2).clue: These gothic architectural supports can be "clasping" or "flying"

(1, 3).clue: His "Decameron" may "appear to have but a harsh and offensive beginning", but he hoped you'd read on

(2, 3).clue: This polysyllabic '50s Italian sexpot had a one-woman exhibit of her sculpture in 2003

(3, 3).clue: Also a type of equation, it describes functions of the formf(x) = ax² + bx + c

(5, 3).clue: Asian location where a notoriously horrible event took place on the night of June 20, 1756

(6, 3).clue: He was Secretary of Agriculture under Nixon & Ford

(1, 4).clue: This Utopian land of Samuel Butler's was located in New Zealand

(2, 4).clue: Ferdinand, who gained renown for doing this on May 3, 1986, was turned into Japanese pet food

(3, 4).clue: The area of a parallelogram equals b times h, short for these two measures

(5, 4).clue: Silver Springs in northern Florida is one of the state's largest water-filled one of these holes

(6, 4).clue: Of the genus Ranunculus, this grassland wild plant has large yellow flowers

(1, 5).clue: There's no dialogue in this author's novel "The Painted Bird"

(2, 5).clue: Once TV's Jennifer Keaton, she grew up to front a rock band called Jaded

(3, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew points to a diagram on the chalkboard.)  In the ratio of s to r, this measure of an angle is similar to the word that the r stands for

(6, 5).clue: Romeo's 2-word interjection when Juliet appears at her window

(0, 0).clue: After his public comments were criticized by FDR, he resigned his Air Corps Reserve commission in April 1941
